title: Value Model Schema
description: Defines the hierarchical structure of value delivered through four core tracks: Product (what we build), Strategy (how we compete/grow), OrgOps (how we operate internally), and Commercial (how we monetize/sell). Each track decomposes value into L1 layers, L2 components, and L3 sub-components with clear activation status, premium flags, and value propositions.
$comment: VALUE MODEL ARCHITECTURE: This schema models the complete value delivery hierarchy across the four fundamental tracks every organization must manage: (1) Product—the capabilities we build for customers (features, experiences, platforms), (2) Strategy—how we compete, position, and grow (GTM, partnerships, market expansion), (3) OrgOps—how we operate and scale internally (team structure, processes, tooling, culture), (4) Commercial—how we monetize and sell (pricing, packaging, sales motions, success programs). Each track follows a three-level decomposition: L1 Layers (major value themes, 5-10 per track), L2 Components (functional groupings, 3-8 per layer), L3 Sub-components (specific capabilities/features, granular units of work). This hierarchical structure enables: Portfolio planning (visualize full value landscape), Prioritization (understand dependencies and sequencing), Communication (align teams on what we're building and why), Roadmapping (plan releases by value layer), Investment tracking (resource allocation across tracks), Premium/tiering (identify paid vs free value). Design principles: (1) Mutual exclusivity (each capability belongs to exactly one track/layer/component), (2) Completeness (model captures all value delivered, not just product features), (3) Actionability (L3 sub-components are concrete, implementable units), (4) Stability (L1/L2 rarely change; L3 evolves frequently), (5) Customer-facing (describe value in customer terms, not internal jargon). Common usage patterns: Product portfolio management (track what's active vs planned), Feature gating (premium flags drive access control), Roadmap planning (sequence sub-components by layer/component), Competitive positioning (identify gaps in value model vs competitors), Sales enablement (link features to value props for pitches), Customer success (track which value customers have activated). Examples: Product track (L1: Core Platform, L2: Data Management, L3: CSV Import, Excel Sync, API Connectors), Strategy track (L1: Market Expansion, L2: Enterprise GTM, L3: Solution Selling Motion, Account-Based Marketing, Executive Engagement Program), OrgOps track (L1: Engineering Excellence, L2: Developer Experience, L3: Local Dev Environment, CI/CD Pipeline, Observability Stack), Commercial track (L1: Monetization, L2: Pricing & Packaging, L3: Usage-Based Pricing, Enterprise Plan, Self-Serve Tier). Best practices: (1) Start with customer value, not implementation, (2) Keep L1 stable (foundational themes rarely change), (3) Evolve L2 as strategy shifts (components emerge/consolidate), (4) Manage L3 actively (features ship, deprecate, get promoted), (5) Link L3 to roadmap (every sub-component maps to initiatives), (6) Use activation status (active/planned/deprecated lifecycle), (7) Mark premium explicitly (avoid confusion on what's paid), (8) Version models (track evolution over time), (9) Validate completeness (walk sales conversations, ensure all value claims are modeled), (10) Review quarterly (value models should reflect current state and near-term plans). Anti-patterns to avoid: Modeling implementation details instead of customer value, L1/L2 that are too granular (should be strategic themes, not features), Missing entire value categories (e.g., no OrgOps or Strategy track), Premium flags without corresponding packaging strategy, Sub-components that are too abstract (should be shippable units), Models that diverge from roadmap reality.

track_name.description: The value track this model represents. Product = what we build for customers (features, experiences, platforms). Strategy = how we compete and grow (GTM, partnerships, positioning, expansion). OrgOps = how we operate internally (processes, tools, culture, team structures). Commercial = how we monetize (pricing, packaging, sales, success). Each track has distinct stakeholders, metrics, and planning horizons.

version.description: Semantic version of this value model (e.g., '2.1.0'). Increment: major version when L1/L2 structure changes significantly (strategic pivot), minor version when L2 components added/removed (capability expansion), patch version when L3 sub-components change (feature-level updates). Version enables tracking evolution, comparing model snapshots, and understanding when major value model shifts occurred.

status.description: Current lifecycle status. 'active' = this track is fully defined and actively managed (default state for operational tracks). 'placeholder' = track structure exists but not yet fully populated with components (use during initial modeling or when planning new tracks). 'deprecated' = track is being sunset and no longer maintained (legacy tracks being replaced or consolidated). Status drives visibility in planning tools and indicates which models are authoritative.

description.description: High-level description of the value this track delivers to the business and customers. Should answer: What is the purpose of this track? Who benefits from it? Why does it exist? Examples: 'Product track delivers customer-facing capabilities that solve core workflow problems and drive product adoption', 'Strategy track ensures we compete effectively in target markets through positioning, partnerships, and go-to-market excellence', 'OrgOps track builds internal operational excellence enabling teams to ship faster and scale efficiently', 'Commercial track drives revenue through effective pricing, packaging, sales motions, and customer success programs'.

packaged_default.description: Whether this is a canonical default value model provided by EPF framework (true) or a custom model for a specific product/organization (false). Packaged defaults serve as templates and starting points—teams typically clone and customize them. When true, indicates this model ships with EPF and should be treated as reference documentation. When false, indicates this is a product-specific customization that evolved from the default template.

activation_notes.description: Instructions and guidance for activating this value model's components in practice. Typically includes: (1) Prerequisites or dependencies for enabling sub-components, (2) Recommended activation sequence (which components to build first), (3) Configuration steps or setup required, (4) Integration points with other tracks or systems, (5) Known gotchas or considerations. Examples: 'Enable core authentication (L3) before activating any premium features', 'Strategy track components require completed market research from Product track', 'OrgOps tooling integrations must be configured before marking sub-components as active'.

high_level_model.description: Product-specific high-level model structure or metadata that doesn't fit the standard L1/L2/L3 hierarchy. Use this for: (1) Cross-track relationships or dependencies, (2) Alternative visualization data (e.g., customer journey mappings), (3) Custom metadata specific to this product's value modeling needs, (4) Rollup metrics or aggregated views, (5) External system references or links. This is a flexible extension point—contents are product-defined and not validated by schema. Common uses: Linking value model to roadmap items, storing competitive positioning data, tracking activation metrics by layer, defining feature flag mappings.

layers.description: L1 layers: major thematic groupings of value within this track. Layers represent the highest level of strategic categorization—they answer 'what are the major pillars of value we deliver in this track?' Typically 5-10 layers per track. Layers are relatively stable (change infrequently, only with strategic pivots). Examples: Product track layers (Core Platform, Data & Analytics, Collaboration, Integrations, Mobile Experience), Strategy track layers (Market Expansion, Competitive Positioning, Partnership Ecosystem, Brand & Community), OrgOps track layers (Engineering Excellence, Data Operations, Security & Compliance, Team Enablement), Commercial track layers (Monetization, Sales Operations, Customer Success, Partner Programs).
layers.$comment: L1 LAYER DESIGN: Layers are the foundational structure of your value model—they define the major 'buckets' of value your organization delivers. A well-designed layer structure is: (1) Stable (layers rarely change, even as features evolve), (2) Mutually exclusive (clear boundaries, no overlap between layers), (3) Collectively exhaustive (together, layers cover all value delivered in this track), (4) Strategic (layers map to business priorities and investment themes), (5) Customer-resonant (even internal tracks should have customer-facing impact). Design principles: (a) Start with customer value or business outcomes, not org structure (layers should reflect what customers/business get, not how teams are organized), (b) Aim for 5-10 layers per track (fewer = too broad to be useful, more = too granular to be strategic), (c) Use noun phrases describing value themes (e.g., 'Data & Analytics', 'Engineering Excellence', 'Market Expansion'), (d) Ensure layers have long shelf life (shouldn't need to change quarterly), (e) Consider dependencies and natural sequences (some layers are foundational, others build on top). Common layer archetypes: (Product) Core Platform (foundational capabilities everyone uses), Add-on Capabilities (specialized features for specific use cases), User Experience (cross-functional UX improvements), Developer Experience (platform extensibility), Scale & Performance (enterprise readiness). (Strategy) Market Expansion (new segments/geos), Competitive Defense (matching/beating competitors), Category Creation (defining new markets), Partnership Ecosystem (joint value with partners). (OrgOps) Team Enablement (tools/processes for productivity), Operational Excellence (efficiency/quality), Culture & People (team health/growth), Infrastructure & Security (foundational systems). (Commercial) Monetization (pricing/packaging), Sales Enablement (tools/content for sales), Customer Success (adoption/retention programs), Partner Programs (channel/reseller motions). Layer evolution: Layers typically evolve through three phases: (1) Emergence (new layer identified as strategic priority, initially has few components), (2) Growth (layer fills out with components and sub-components as investment increases), (3) Maturity (layer is well-defined, components are stable, focus shifts to optimization). Rarely should layers be removed—if a layer is no longer strategic, mark its status as deprecated rather than deleting (preserves historical context). Examples: Product track for SaaS CRM (Layers: Core CRM, Sales Automation, Marketing Automation, Customer Service, Analytics & Reporting, Mobile & Collaboration, Integrations & APIs, Platform & Extensibility), Strategy track (Layers: Enterprise GTM, SMB Acquisition, Product-Led Growth, Strategic Partnerships, International Expansion, Brand & Community), OrgOps track (Layers: Engineering Systems, Data & Analytics Operations, Security & Compliance, People & Culture, Finance & Operations), Commercial track (Layers: Pricing & Packaging, Sales Operations, Customer Success Operations, Channel & Partnerships).

id.description: Unique identifier for this L1 layer (kebab-case recommended). Used to reference this layer in roadmaps, analytics, and cross-model relationships. Should be stable across model versions. Examples: 'core-platform', 'market-expansion', 'engineering-excellence', 'sales-operations'. IDs enable programmatic access and linking—keep them stable even if layer names evolve.

name.description: Display name for this layer (what appears in UIs and documentation). Use clear, customer-friendly language (even for internal tracks). Examples: 'Core Platform', 'Market Expansion', 'Engineering Excellence', 'Sales Operations'. Names should be self-explanatory—avoid acronyms or internal jargon.

description.description: Detailed explanation of this layer's purpose, scope, and strategic importance. Should answer: What value does this layer deliver? Who benefits? Why does it exist? What components/sub-components belong here? How does this layer connect to business goals? Examples: 'Core Platform provides foundational capabilities every user needs: data modeling, workflow automation, collaboration, and core UX. These features drive initial adoption and enable all other layers.' Include strategic context, customer impact, and boundaries.

solution_steps.description: Layer-specific implementation approach explaining HOW this layer delivers value. Each step describes a concrete implementation action and its resulting capability. This complements the layer description (WHAT the layer does) by explaining the activation sequence (HOW value is generated). Typically 3-5 steps per layer. Examples: Step 'Expose RESTful and GraphQL APIs for workflow operations' → Outcome 'AI agents can initiate workflows programmatically'. Pattern: action-oriented steps that build upon each other, outcomes that describe capabilities unlocked.

step.description: Implementation action describing HOW value is delivered at this layer. Use action verbs (Implement, Build, Enable, Provide, Configure). Focus on capabilities being created, not technical details. Keep layer-appropriate scope (broader than component-level details). Examples: 'Implement workspace isolation with row-level security', 'Expose REST/GraphQL API for workflow operations', 'Deploy comprehensive monitoring stack'. Should be 30-150 characters.

outcome.description: Resulting capability or value unlocked by this step. Answers 'So that...' - what becomes possible after this step is complete? Focus on user/business benefits, not technical specifications. Examples: 'Multiple product lines operate independently without data leakage', 'AI agents can initiate workflows programmatically', 'System failures detected instantly before users impacted'. Should be 30-200 characters.

components.description: L2 components: functional groupings of related sub-components within this layer. Components are mid-level organizing structure—they answer 'how is value in this layer delivered? what are the key functional areas?' Typically 3-8 components per layer. Components evolve more than layers but less than sub-components—they might be added as new capabilities emerge or removed as areas consolidate. Examples: 'Data Management' component within 'Core Platform' layer contains sub-components like CSV Import, Excel Sync, API Connectors.
components.$comment: L2 COMPONENT DESIGN: Components are the functional building blocks of layers—they group related sub-components (features/capabilities) into meaningful clusters. A well-designed component is: (1) Cohesive (sub-components within it are tightly related), (2) Loosely coupled (minimal dependencies on other components), (3) Right-sized (typically 3-8 sub-components per component), (4) User-understandable (matches how customers think about features), (5) Implementable (maps to team ownership and roadmap). Design principles: (a) Group by customer workflow or job-to-be-done (not by technical architecture), (b) Aim for 3-8 components per layer (balance detail with manageability), (c) Use noun phrases describing functional areas (e.g., 'Data Management', 'User Authentication', 'Reporting & Analytics'), (d) Ensure components have clear boundaries (avoid overlap, ensure every sub-component has obvious home), (e) Consider natural feature clusters (features that ship together or are used together should be in same component). Common component patterns: (Product) By workflow (Onboarding, Daily Operations, Reporting), by user role (Admin Features, End-User Features, Developer Features), by functional domain (Data, Workflow, Collaboration). (Strategy) By go-to-market motion (Enterprise Sales, Product-Led Growth, Channel Partnerships), by market segment (SMB, Mid-Market, Enterprise), by geographic region (North America, EMEA, APAC). (OrgOps) By operational area (Engineering, Data, Security, People), by capability type (Processes, Tools, Culture), by team/function (Platform Team, Product Team, Data Team). (Commercial) By revenue motion (New Sales, Expansion, Renewals), by customer lifecycle stage (Acquisition, Activation, Retention), by channel (Direct Sales, Channel Partners, Self-Serve). Component evolution: Components are added when: new functional areas emerge (e.g., 'AI Features' component when AI becomes strategic), existing components become too large (split 'Reports' into 'Standard Reports' and 'Custom Analytics'), new use cases require distinct grouping (e.g., 'Mobile-Specific Features' when mobile becomes priority). Components are removed when: features are deprecated and component becomes empty, areas consolidate (merge 'Basic Reports' and 'Advanced Reports' into 'Reporting'), strategic shifts render them obsolete. Examples: Product track 'Core Platform' layer components (Data Management, Workflow Automation, User & Permissions, Notifications & Alerts, Search & Discovery), Strategy track 'Market Expansion' layer components (Enterprise GTM, SMB Acquisition, International Markets, Vertical Solutions), OrgOps track 'Engineering Excellence' layer components (Developer Tooling, CI/CD Pipeline, Code Quality, Incident Response), Commercial track 'Monetization' layer components (Pricing Strategy, Packaging Tiers, Usage-Based Billing, Contract Management).

id.description: Unique identifier for this L2 component within the layer (kebab-case). Format: typically include layer context or keep globally unique. Examples: 'data-management', 'user-authentication', 'enterprise-gtm', 'developer-tooling'. Used for referencing in roadmaps, analytics, and documentation.

name.description: Display name for this component (customer-friendly, appears in UIs). Use clear functional descriptions. Examples: 'Data Management', 'User Authentication', 'Enterprise GTM', 'Developer Tooling'. Should immediately communicate what functional area this represents.

description.description: Explanation of this component's purpose, scope, and how it delivers value within the layer. Should answer: What does this component do? What sub-components does it contain? How does it fit into the broader layer? Examples: 'Data Management component enables users to import, export, sync, and transform data across systems. Includes CSV/Excel import, API connectors, real-time sync, and data validation capabilities.' Provides context for understanding sub-component grouping.

sub_components.description: L3 sub-components: granular, shippable units of value (features, capabilities, specific programs). Sub-components are the most detailed level—they answer 'what specific capabilities exist within this component?' These are the units of work for roadmap planning, feature flagging, and release management. Each sub-component should be independently shippable and customer-facing (or internally deliverable for OrgOps/Strategy tracks). Typically dozens to hundreds of sub-components per value model.
sub_components.$comment: L3 SUB-COMPONENT DESIGN: Sub-components are the atomic units of value delivery—individual features, capabilities, or programs that can be built, shipped, activated, and measured independently. A well-designed sub-component is: (1) Shippable (can be delivered as a discrete unit), (2) Testable (has clear success criteria and can be validated), (3) Valuable (delivers tangible benefit to users or business when activated), (4) Describable (can be explained in a single sentence), (5) Trackable (can have metrics, activation status, roadmap linkage). Design principles: (a) Keep granularity appropriate for planning (not too small—'Add button'—not too large—'Complete redesign'), (b) Make sub-components customer-facing in description (even for internal features, describe the impact), (c) Ensure independence (sub-component can be shipped without requiring others in same batch), (d) Use action-oriented names (describe what users can do, not just what exists), (e) Link to value props (each sub-component should map to customer benefits). Sub-component attributes: (1) Active flag (is this currently available/built?), (2) Premium flag (is this paid/gated?), (3) UVP (unique value proposition—how does this help customers?), (4) ID (stable reference), (5) Name (customer-facing label). Sub-component lifecycle: Start as 'active: false' (planned/on roadmap), move to 'active: true' when shipped and available, eventually deprecate (remove or mark inactive) when sunset. Premium designation determines: feature gating, sales positioning, packaging/pricing strategy, competitive differentiation. Common sub-component patterns: (Product) Feature-level (CSV Import, Advanced Filters, Real-Time Sync, Customizable Dashboards, Bulk Actions, Email Templates, Mobile App, API Rate Limiting), capability-level (Single Sign-On, Role-Based Permissions, Audit Logs, Webhooks, White-Labeling), experience-level (Onboarding Wizard, In-App Help, Keyboard Shortcuts, Dark Mode). (Strategy) Program-level (Executive Engagement Program, Solution Selling Playbook, Account-Based Marketing Campaign, Competitive Battle Cards), initiative-level (EMEA Market Entry, Vertical Go-to-Market, Strategic Partnership with {Partner}, Category Creation Campaign). (OrgOps) Tooling (Local Dev Environment, CI/CD Pipeline, Log Aggregation, Performance Monitoring, Incident Response Runbook), process (Code Review Standards, Release Process, On-Call Rotation, Sprint Planning Template), culture (Engineering Principles Document, Career Ladder, Learning & Development Program). (Commercial) Pricing mechanics (Usage-Based Pricing, Enterprise Contracts, Volume Discounts, Free Trial), packaging (Starter Tier, Professional Tier, Enterprise Tier, Add-On Modules), programs (Customer Success Onboarding, Renewal Playbook, Expansion Sales Motion, Partner Certification). Examples: Product track 'Data Management' component sub-components (CSV Import, Excel Import, Google Sheets Sync, Salesforce Integration, REST API Connector, Bulk Export, Data Validation Rules, Field Mapping UI, Scheduled Sync, Webhook Triggers), Strategy track 'Enterprise GTM' component sub-components (Enterprise Sales Playbook, Solution Selling Training, Executive Engagement Program, Account-Based Marketing, Strategic Account Planning, Enterprise Pricing Calculator, RFP Response Library), OrgOps track 'Developer Tooling' component sub-components (Local Dev Environment Setup, VS Code Extensions, Code Generation CLI, Automated Testing Framework, Performance Profiler, Debugging Tools), Commercial track 'Pricing Strategy' component sub-components (Usage-Based Pricing Model, Per-Seat Pricing, Feature-Based Packaging, Enterprise Contract Templates, Discount Approval Workflow).

id.description: Unique identifier for this L3 sub-component (kebab-case). Should be globally unique across all tracks/layers/components. Examples: 'csv-import', 'sso-authentication', 'enterprise-pricing', 'code-review-process'. Used extensively for: feature flags, roadmap tracking, analytics, customer entitlements, documentation linking. Keep IDs stable—changing them breaks references.

name.description: Customer-facing name for this sub-component (appears in UIs, documentation, sales materials). Use clear, benefit-oriented language. Examples: 'CSV Import', 'Single Sign-On', 'Enterprise Contracts', 'Code Review Standards'. For Product features, focus on what users can do. For Strategy/OrgOps/Commercial, describe the program or capability.

active.description: Whether this sub-component is currently available and active (true) or planned/not yet built (false). Use active=true when: feature is shipped and available to customers (even if behind feature flag), program is launched and operational, capability is built and enabled. Use active=false when: feature is on roadmap but not yet built, program is planned but not operational, capability is deprecated or sunset. This flag drives: feature availability checks, roadmap progress tracking, customer entitlement validation, sales enablement (what to sell).

premium.description: Whether this is a paid/gated capability (true) or included in base/free offering (false). Premium designation determines: Feature gating (requires paid plan to access), Sales positioning (key differentiator for upsells), Competitive advantage (capabilities competitors don't have), Pricing/packaging strategy (which tiers include this). Set premium=true for: Enterprise-only features, advanced capabilities that justify higher pricing, features that drive upsells/expansions, competitive differentiators. Set premium=false for: Core capabilities everyone needs, features in free/base plans, table-stakes functionality. Premium strategy varies by business model: Product-Led Growth (generous free tier, premium for scale/advanced features), Enterprise Sales (core features free, premium for enterprise capabilities), Vertical SaaS (base features free, industry-specific premium).

uvp.description: Unique Value Proposition: customer-facing benefit statement for this sub-component. Should answer: What problem does this solve? What outcome does it enable? Why should customers care? Format as a single sentence or short phrase focusing on customer impact (not technical details). Examples: 'Import thousands of records in seconds, no manual data entry required' (CSV Import), 'Secure enterprise access with your existing identity provider' (SSO), 'Get dedicated support and SLAs for mission-critical operations' (Enterprise Support), 'Ship faster with automated testing and deployment pipelines' (CI/CD). Good UVPs are: Customer-centric (focus on their benefit, not our technology), Specific (quantify when possible: '10x faster', '99.9% uptime'), Outcome-oriented (what they achieve, not what they do), Differentiating (why this matters vs alternatives). Use UVPs in: Sales pitches and demos, Marketing copy and landing pages, In-app onboarding and education, Feature comparison charts, Customer success communications.
